dict.string:
Active Voice
Subject PERFORMS the action of the verb
Passive Voice
Focuses on action rather than the subject
Example
Active
He writes a letter
Passive
A letter is written by him

How to change active to passive
Move the subject to the beginning of the sentence

Example:
Passive Voice:
The tree was hit by the car
Active Voice:
The car hit the tree

How to change passive to active
Change the SUBJECT to be the OBJECT of the VERB.

Example:
Passive Voice:
The car hit the tree
Active Voice:
The tree was hit by the car

When to use active and passive

Passive voice is used to avoid taking responsibility for an action

Active voice is direct,clear, and concise. 

Passive voice is awkward when an author uses "it" as the receiver rather than using "I" or "we"

Example
It is concluded that the treatment is effective.

If passive voice is not constructed properly,it may have grammatical errors such as Dangling modifiers

Example:
Incorrect passive voice
To investigate the source of nutrients, eggshell membranes were compared.

The phrase modifies the only subject "eggshell". The sentence is not clear.

Corrected sentence
To investigate the source of nutrients, we compared eggshell membranes

Don't Underestimate These Three Little Words

In English, there are only three articles: the, a, and an

These three are not interchangeable; rather, they are used
in specific instances.

There are two types of articles:
  • Indefinite articles (an,a)
  • Definite articles ( the )

How do I know which one to use?
The answer is quite simple.
For indefinite article:
Use 'a ' before nouns (or adjectives) that start with a consonant sound.
Use 'an' before singular nouns (or adjectives) that start with a vowel sound.

Example:
  • Please give the dog a cookie. 
  • That's an old car.
Remember:
  • an hour
In the above sentence, You might think that 'a'
must come before a constant. But hour pronounced
like our which gives a vowel sound.

  •  A union
The word may start with a u, but 'union' is pronounced
as you-union. Therefore we have to use 'a'.

The definite article (the)
'The' is used before singular and plural nouns
when the noun is specific or particular.
'The' signals that the noun is definite.
Example:

"The dog that bit me ran away"
Here, we're talking about a specific dog, the dog that bit me.

Wrong sentence:
Aeroplane is the fastest means of travel that is in common use.
Correct sentence:
The Aeroplane is the fastest means of travel that is in common use

Wrong sentence:
He gave me an advice.
Correct sentence:
He gave me some advice.
Note:
'a' and 'an' are used before countable nouns.
When uncountable noun (advice) is used, 'some' is used.

Dangling participles

Dangling participles are tricky words or phrases that change the meaning of a sentence so that we don't say exactly what we intend.

What is a participle?
A participle usually acts a adjective.
 These are usually noun forms of the verbs.
Example:
Hiking shoes.

Participle phrases
These are just phrases that contain a participle and modify the sentence.
Example
Floating in the pool, I marveled at the clouds
"Floating" is the participle in the phrase "floating in the pool
It modifies the subject "I"

Example:
Biting his victim, the vampire felt a momentary thrill.

Dangling Participles:

When you dangle a participle, it means your participial phrase is hanging
 there in your sentence with no proper subject in sight.
Example
Hiking the trail, the birds chirped loudly.

In the above sentence, it seems that it is the birds hiking the trail

Correct sentence:
Hiking the trail, Squiggly and Aardvark heard birds chirping loudly.

More Examples
Rushing to the catch the bus, Bob's wallet fell out of his pocket.
Flying south for the winter, I saw a huge flock of swallows.
Walking along the beach, the sun rose majestically over the ocean

How to fix it
Add the subject to which the phrase is referring to and rephrase he sentence.

Parts of Speech
Each part of speech explains how the word is used.
 
There are seven parts of speech in English
  • Nouns
  • Verbs
  • Pronouns
  • Adjective
  • Adverbs
  • Preposition
  • Conjunction

Important classes:
  1. Nouns-  These are names of people things or ideas.Eg: man,car,India
  2. Verbs-   Action words Eg:go, eat, sit,stand.
  3. Adjectives- These describe nouns. Eg: old man, Dangerous man.
  4. Adverbs- These describe verbs.(Ends in -ly).  Eg: beautifully.
  5. Perpostions: Short words used before a noun to show time or place.

Common Mistakes:
  • Many people prefer to buy Malaysia products.
  • That man is a Dangerously driver.

Correct sentence:
  • Many people prefer to buy Malaysian Product.
  • That man is a dangerous driver.
Explanation:
1) 'Malaysia' and 'product' are nouns.  A noun cannot describe a noun.
     Thefore adjective Malaysian must be used.
2)  Dangerously is an adverb; To describe the noun ‘driver’,
      the adjective dangerous must be used.

Noun or Adjectives

Typical mistakes:
  • My sister is an intelligence person
  • All races must live in peaceful and harmony
Correct sentence:
  •  My sister is an intelligent person.
  •  All races must live in peace and harmony.
Explanation:
1) Adjective is needed to describe a noun (person)
2) a preposition (in) always follows by a noun.

Pronouns
Pronouns are small words that the place of a noun.
If we didn't have pronouns, we would have to repeat a lot of nouns.

Example
Sentence without pronoun
Do you like the president? I don't like the president. The president is too pompous.
Sentence with pronoun
Do you like the president? I don't like him. He is too pompous.

Types of pronouns

Personal Pronouns
I, me, you, he, him, she...

Demonstrative Pronouns
this, that, these, those

Possessive Pronouns
mine, yours, his...

Reflexive Pronouns
myself, yourself, himself...

Relative Pronouns
who, whom, which...

Subject Verb Agreement
If you want to write proper English, you have to follow a rule called "subject-verb agreement."

Two basic rules
If the subject is singular, the verb needs to be singular.
If the subject is plural, the verb needs to be plural.

Examples
The duck quacks. (singular subject with singular verb)
Ducks quack.    (plural subject with plural verb)

The problem

The problem arises when there are two subjects.
In such cases you may have problems in deciding to which subject the verb should agree.

There are six rules which will make things clear.

Rule 1
Two singular subjects connected with "and" are plural, and need a plural verb.

Example
My mother and my father are visiting me.


Wrong usuage:
My mother and my father is visiting me.

Rule 2
Two singular subjects connected with the conjunctions or or nor need a singular verb.

Example
My mother or my father is going to call me today.

Note
If one of the subjects is plural, use the plural verb
We put the plural subject closest to the verb.
In other words,the verb agrees with the closest subject.
Example
The general or his advisers are responsible for the decision
advisors-plural. and closest to the verb.

Rule 3
Don’t get distracted if there’s another phrase between the subject and the verb.

Example
My sister, along with her children, is visiting me next month.

The verb needs to agree with the subject, not with other nouns that happen to precede the verb.

Rule 4
Words such as
  • either
  • neither
  • everyone 
  • everybody
  • anyone 
  • anybody 
  • someone
  • one
  • none 
  • each
are singular and need a singular verb.
Example:
One of my friends is playing football.

Rule 5
fractions or portions of a plural noun are still plural
often these are expressed with prepositions.
Points to remember
Use a singular verb if the object of the preposition is singular, but a plural verb if it’s plural.
Example:
  • Some of the students are wealthy
  • Half of the campus is covered with trees.

Rule 6
Time and money are singular
Example:
Five rupees is very little money

Positive Degree
This form can be used to compare items when combined with 'as'.
Example
Josh is as smart as kelsey
Note:
The adjective(smart) is placed between "as".
The adjective is unaltered.
Example
His house is not as big as that one.
big-adjective.

Comparative degree
It is used when you compare two objects
"-er" is added to the adjective
    smart-er
    fast-er
    smooth-er
But sometimes you need to add more or less before the adjective.
    less attractive
    more attractive
Example
This house is bigger than that one
This flower is more beautiful than that.

Comparative degree
When to add "more" or "-er"
Most one syllable and two syllable adjectives that end in "y" end in "-er"

Eg:calmer.
Adjectives with more than two syllables use "more"
Eg: more beautiful.
However there are exceptions to this. Refer the dictionary.
Important Point
When you are using adjectives ending "-er" in the same list with adjectives that use "more",
the adjective with "more" should come last in the list.
Example:
She is smarter,smaller, and more beautiful than kylie is

Superlative Degree
Compares three or more items and is considered the greatest degree.
Many superlatives end with -est
Eg: smartest,fastest and smoothest
Example
He has the highest grade in the group.
Irregular adjectives
These words are irregular because you have to change the entire word instead of just adding -er or -est.
For example
little--less-least.
good-better-best.
